fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

- open Firefox 2.0.0.20 (the latest stable version of Firefox 2)
- create a page tree with 15 or more levels of nesting
- on the deeply nested page click 'View in Hierarchy'
- the page tree takes a very long time to expand (~10 seconds for 15 levels, going up exponentially as you add more levels).

The page tree gets progressively slower in Firefox 2. This seems to be because it is expensive to call element.offsetHeight (or .clientHeight).

At the moment, it isn't something we can fix without rewriting much of the tree component. We recommend people experiencing this problem upgrade to Firefox 3 or later.
fields.summary: Page tree with deep nesting becomes very slow to expand in Firefox 2

fields.description:
This is the new hierarchy for attachments in the file system:
!http://confluence.atlassian.com/download/attachments/179442774/attachmentstorage.png?version=4&modificationDate=1234484336367!

As you can see there are 9 levels including the 'ver003' folder. I found that if you are missing level 8 and 9 in the file system, Confluence can still move the page without any complain. If you are missing level 7 (content id) then it will complain and throw you a stack trace, also failing the move operation:
{noformat}
Cause

com.atlassian.confluence.pages.persistence.dao.UpdateAttachmentsOnFileSystemException: Failed to move the attachment data
at com.atlassian.confluence.pages.persistence.dao.UpdateAttachmentsOnFilesystemOnPageMoveListener.moveAttachments(UpdateAttachmentsOnFilesystemOnPageMoveListener.java:94)

caused by: java.io.FileNotFoundException: Source 'C:\confluencedata_mysql\attachments\ver003\187\36\786437\118\221\721118' does not exist
at org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils.moveDirectory(FileUtils.java:1733)
Stack Trace:[hide]

com.atlassian.confluence.pages.persistence.dao.UpdateAttachmentsOnFileSystemException: Failed to move the attachment data
at com.atlassian.confluence.pages.persistence.dao.UpdateAttachmentsOnFilesystemOnPageMoveListener.moveAttachments(UpdateAttachmentsOnFilesystemOnPageMoveListener.java:94)
at com.atlassian.confluence.pages.persistence.dao.UpdateAttachmentsOnFilesystemOnPageMoveListener.handleEvent(UpdateAttachmentsOnFilesystemOnPageMoveListener.java:67)
at com.atlassian.event.DefaultEventManager$2.run(DefaultEventManager.java:202)
{noformat}

In the above, *721118* is the contentid.

The message is a bit rude and it can be improved perhaps by informing the users that the attachments are not there and/or Confluence should ask whether they want to proceed with the move operation or not.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-17574].
  {panel}

Any java written application which interfaces with Confluence as a client, via the SOAP and/or XML/RPC interface, because they are themselves their own JVM, maintain a list of 'clean' and 'dirty', references to objects which the client knows about, across the wire.

When a remote client of Confluence calls a regular System.gc() as a part of it's usual automated garbage collection routine, it will notify the remote peer (in this case, Confluence), that any objects it was holding, of which Confluence was tracking in it's own reference object graph, are now dirty and those references should be cleaned.

Currently the Hotspot JVM performs this action as a serial, single-threaded System garbage collection. This can lead to rare circumstances whereby a remote client, if poorly written, or resource starved in the JVM, can fatally spam Confluence with full system GC calls until (if) it recovers.

The effect is similar to:
{noformat}378.030: [GC [PSYoungGen: 13733K->10886K(418816K)] 257769K->254922K(1336320K), 0.0438305 secs] [Times: user=0.05 sys=0.00, real=0.05 secs] 
378.074: [Full GC (System) [PSYoungGen: 10886K->0K(418816K)] [ParOldGen: 244036K->244138K(917504K)] 254922K->244138K(1336320K) [PSPermGen: 66190K->66190K(135168K)], 1.5175107 secs] [Times: user=4.92 sys=0.05, real=1.51 secs] 
379.924: [GC [PSYoungGen: 15258K->712K(435328K)] 259396K->244850K(1352832K), 0.0091928 secs] [Times: user=0.00 sys=0.00, real=0.02 secs] 
379.933: [Full GC (System) [PSYoungGen: 712K->0K(435328K)] [ParOldGen: 244138K->240486K(917504K)] 244850K->240486K(1352832K) [PSPermGen: 66592K->66590K(131072K)], 1.6306610 secs] [Times: user=4.53 sys=0.00, real=1.63 secs] 
382.535: [GC [PSYoungGen: 19106K->11462K(431104K)] 259592K->251948K(1348608K), 0.0230824 secs] [Times: user=0.06 sys=0.00, real=0.03 secs] 
382.558: [Full GC (System) [PSYoungGen: 11462K->0K(431104K)] [ParOldGen: 240486K->240176K(917504K)] 251948K->240176K(1348608K) [PSPermGen: 66648K->66646K(131072K)], 1.3173999 secs] [Times: user=4.14 sys=0.00, real=1.31 secs] 
383.926: [GC [PSYoungGen: 12066K->5636K(446080K)] 252242K->245812K(1363584K), 0.0219822 secs] [Times: user=0.05 sys=0.00, real=0.03 secs] 
383.949: [Full GC (System) [PSYoungGen: 5636K->0K(446080K)] [ParOldGen: 240176K->245655K(917504K)] 245812K->245655K(1363584K) [PSPermGen: 66668K->66668K(131072K)], 1.2802751 secs] [Times: user=4.03 sys=0.00, real=1.27 secs] 
385.301: [GC [PSYoungGen: 7271K->224K(441408K)] 252926K->245879K(1358912K), 0.0217929 secs] [Times: user=0.03 sys=0.00, real=0.03 secs] {noformat}
Rendering the installation incapacitated.

From [Sun|http://java.sun.com/javase/technologies/hotspot/gc/gc_tuning_6.html#other_considerations]:

{quote}Another way applications can interact with garbage collection is by invoking full garbage collections explicitly by calling System.gc(). This can force a major collection to be done when it may not be necessary (i.e., when a minor collection would suffice), and so in general should be avoided. The performance impact of explicit garbage collections can be measured by disabling them using the flag -XX:+DisableExplicitGC, which causes the VM to ignore calls to System.gc().

One of the most commonly encountered uses of explicit garbage collection occurs with RMI's distributed garbage collection (DGC). Applications using RMI refer to objects in other virtual machines. Garbage cannot be collected in these distributed applications without occasionally collection the local heap, so RMI forces full collections periodically. {quote}Alternatively,{quote}The frequency of these collections can be controlled with properties. For example,

	 java -Dsun.rmi.dgc.client.gcInterval=3600000 -Dsun.rmi.dgc.server.gcInterval=3600000 ...
 
specifies explicit collection once per hour instead of the default rate of once per minute. However, this may also cause some objects to take much longer to be reclaimed. These properties can be set as high as Long.MAX_VALUE to make the time between explicit collections effectively infinite, if there is no desire for an upper bound on the timeliness of DGC activity.{quote}

Originates from [CSP-38789|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CSP-38789]. Explicit remote GC can be completely disabled (ignored) via {{-XX:+DisableExplicitGC}} in Tomcat startup parameters, under Sun Hotspot. Recommend we add this to the distribution startup parameters. Ignoring client requests for GC should not have any impact moving forward as Confluence has already been notified that the object is dirty, or dereferenced, and will reclaim it as part of normal collections.
fields.summary: disable distributed garbage collection via RMI

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-17557].
  {panel}

There are a few consistency problems that would be good to fix in the new Gadget Directory before we ship it.

- The wording 'Click here for ...' is against our conventions for link text in Confluence. We don't say 'Click here', rather the link text should be a description of what is found at the destination of the link. Change this to something like 'Confluence Gadget Documentation'.
- The text 'Click here for ...' is too large. It should be the same size as the text above it.
- There is a hover background colour on the gadget specs, but they aren't clickable. You should only use hover highlighting when the target is clickable.
- The description for the Activity Stream says, 'Lists recent activity in a single project, or in all projects.', but we don't have projects in Confluence. Should it say 'space'/'spaces' instead?
- The gadget thumbnails are scaled down here like in the macro browser when they don't need to be. (I presume they're scaled down. If they're not, we need to recreate those images because they look badly scaled.)

Some improvement ideas:

- Make the text 'By Atlassian' and 'Gadget URL' smaller (or greyer, or both) so that the title and description are more obvious. The latter are the important pieces of information, so they should stand out a bit more.
- Make the font for the description text in the left panel the same size as the body font on the right-hand side.
- Put some short introductory text in the dialog. Either above the 'How to use these gadgets' on the left, or in a panel above the gadgets on the right. It should explain what gadgets are: 'Gadgets allow you to display Confluence content and information in other applications.'
fields.summary: Consistency and UI improvements for gadget directory

fields.description:
Currently language pack plugins may include an internalized properties files for i18n resources defined in plugins. Confluence loads language pack and if it finds an properties file that has the same name/path as defined in a plugin's i18n resource it suppose to use it. It works correctly if a language pack is within WEB-INF/lib however it does not work if a language pack is loaded dynamically.

This happens because property files is loaded through the plugin that defines the i18n resource i.e. it uses plugin's classloader. Because plugin's classloader does not 'see' the file defined in a language pack the file does not gets loaded when a bundle is constructed. If a language pack is on the classpath than the plugin's loader can see the files defined in the language pack.
fields.summary: Confluence ignores plugin's i18n files from a language packs if the language pack plugin is loaded dynamically (not on a classpath)

fields.description:
Rather than rendering email in a 
...
block, Confluence "html-ifies" plain-text email messages. If a message contains an inline PGP signature, this corrupts the message so that the signature can no longer be verified. Ideally, it should be possible to do something like: curl http://confluence.example.com/display/SPACENAME/mail/xxxxxx | gpg --verify Or for a plugin like FireGPG to verify inline signatures. Because of the modifications Confluence makes to email this is not possible. This has become an issue locally because we are using the mail archive feature to archive PGP signed messages, and we are presenting them to a tech- and security-savvy user community.
fields.summary: Display of email messages corrupts inline PGP signatures

fields.description:
Since Confluence 3.1.x bundles it own version of the xerces parser (xercesImpl-2.9.1.jar specifically), attempting to start it up will result in this error: 

{noformat}ERROR [JBossContextConfig] XML error parsing: context.xml 
org.jboss.xb.binding.JBossXBRuntimeException: Failed to create a new SAX parser 
     at org.jboss.xb.binding.UnmarshallerFactory$UnmarshallerFactoryImpl.newUnmarshaller(UnmarshallerFactory.java:100) 
     at org.jboss.web.tomcat.service.deployers.JBossContextConfig.processContextConfig(JBossContextConfig.java:552) 
     at org.jboss.web.tomcat.service.deployers.JBossContextConfig.init(JBossContextConfig.java:538) 
     at org.apache.catalina.startup.ContextConfig.lifecycleEvent(ContextConfig.java:279)
{noformat}

Attempting to remove Confluence's version and fallback on the version bundled with JBoss will result in the following error during as the user attempts to progress through the Confluence Setup Wizard: 

{noformat}com.atlassian.plugin.event.NotificationException: com.atlassian.plugin.osgi.container.OsgiContainerException: Detected an incompatible version of Apache Xerces on the classpath. If using Tomcat, you may have an old version of Xerces in $TOMCAT_HOME/common/lib/endorsed that will need to be removed.
	at com.atlassian.plugin.event.impl.DefaultPluginEventManager.broadcast(DefaultPluginEventManager.java:85)
	at com.atlassian.plugin.manager.DefaultPluginManager.init(DefaultPluginManager.java:127)
{noformat}

The above exception is thrown due newer versions of the atlassian-plugin module that is stricter about older versions of xerces in the classpath (see https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/PLUG-414). 

In order to support JBoss, we need a context that is isolated from their WAR classloader. See https://jira.jboss.org/jira/browse/JBAS-7210. 

JIRA 4.0 has the same issue and is also waiting for this fix.
fields.summary: Support JBoss 4.2.3 and 5.0.x in Confluence 3.1.x

fields.description:
We have had problems reported against the new Page Restrictions dialog for EAC running 3.1-beta, where a user clicks the restrictions menu item and nothing is displayed, and the JavaScript console indicates that a required DOM element doesn't exist.

This occurs because the Restrictions Dialog depends on templates that are included via page.vmd, but users can change page.vmd by changing Layout in Space or site Admin. Once the two page.vmds diverge it's difficult to merge them again, and it's an ongoing maintenance task as the page.vmd is updated with new Confluence releases.

The Layout that can be customised by the user should not be mixed with Velocity markup for including required templates and variables, as it confuses back-end logic with presentation.
fields.summary: UI features relying on page.vmd are lost if space/site has a custom Layout

fields.description:
G'day all from New York City!

I've been using Confluence RSS feeds for a number of years and there's definitely something weird with them. On most RSS readers I use I can get the initial subscription, but then my reader won't show any subsequent updates. The only way to see them is to delete the subscription, and resubscribe, but obviously that's not much use.

I've got around this before by finding an RSS reader that doesn't exhibit this problem, e.g. NetNewsWire on OS X or SharpReader on Windows (it can't be a web-based RSS reader because this is for authenticated company internal feeds.) I mostly use OS X so up till now its been my preferred RSS reader, but a couple of weeks ago I switched to Apple Mail because NetNewsWire doesn't play well Sharepoint RSS feeds.

So now I'm stuck with having 2 RSS readers - NetNewsWire for Confluence and Apple Mail for everything else.

One interesting thing is that we also use Fisheye here, and its RSS feeds work fine in Apple Mail.

If you need any more diagnostic information let me know - I'd be keen to see this fixed if possible.

Thanks!

Mike
fields.summary: Problems getting updates for RSS feeds

fields.description:
I recieved a question from a user regarding where the "word functionality" in Confluence was. 
My default page uses the default Theme, from which I gave a screenshot and instructions for using "edit in word". 
The problem was that the page the user wishes to edit uses Left Navigation Theme, which lacks "edit in word" functionality. I supplied a workaround url for the word plugin to make it work from any page. However, word functionality will not be "usable" for the major set of users, who barely get around with word.

A different problem I've faced when choosing a menu theme for a space is that the default theme is probably the better for many spaces. However, a small set of links to other pages in the space/other space could help navigating around the site. I also believe that getting users to understand a simple structure of the entire wiki helps alot, and the left navigation menu has made a big difference.
However, the left menu occupies a lot of space, lacks functionality, and could perhaps be replaced by a default menu with a "floating" list of links to relevant places.

Can you revise the menu themes so one does'nt loose functionality by choosing a different theme.
fields.summary: Inconsistent functionality between menus (themes)

fields.description: I just tried to *insert* a table into the RTE, and the first place I naturally looked was the 'Insert' menu. But it isn't there, which seems a bit odd.
fields.summary: Insert Table link should be included in the Insert menu

fields.description:
From blitz test - a user unfamiliar with the Restrictions dialog found it confusing to use. 

There isn't much text on it at the moment - it assumes that users are familiar with the restrictions UI in previous versions.

We sat together and went through the points of confusion, and suggested text that would make it more obvious how the dialog is supposed to be used. See attached.


_Update_

Summarizing the comments below the following changes should be made:

    * Revert the radio buttons to what they said before
    * Change the text of the entry field (we did have an old wording that used username&groupname)
    * Include a link to the documentation.
fields.summary: Improve explanatory text on Page Restrictions dialog
Improve string used for encoding test

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-17513].
  {panel}

New  PDF export functionality in 3.0 allows for a single title page within a given space, however, this does not seem sufficient.

We generally store content which feeds multiple "publishable documents" within a single space within Confluence, where a "publishable document" is a set of pages that I would want to export as a PDF, and have its own cover page, etc. 

For each "publishable document", it should therefore be possible to define the following:

* Its own title page (or possibly use to a header page "template", where it would then only be necessary to specify 1 or 2 variables for this specific document - such as title and version)
* Its own header
* Its own footer
* The specific set of pages (or pagetree) that should be published for this document

A "non-privileged" user should be able to define these title pages (as opposed to a space administrator).

Further comments related to this improvement request are listed here listed here: http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/KIHjCg
fields.summary: PDF Export should allow for more than one title page, and more than one "publishable documents" from a given space

fields.description: Footer appears in the middle of the page instead at the end.
fields.summary: Footer broken on the edit layout page

fields.description:
The mechanism we use to read bundled plugins involves the atlassian-bundled-plugins.zip being read via the class loader and extracted into individual plugins, which are then loaded again via the PluginClassLoader.

However, on Tomcat at least, the WebappClassLoader will retain the atlassian-bundled-plugins.zip for the duration of the server running, which means for Confluence 3.1-beta1 you have 45Mb of memory being needlessly used.

I've made this minor because 45Mb is a pretty small percentage of Confluence's entire memory requirement, but it's still quite a load of memory.
fields.summary: Bundled plugin loading mechanism leads to larger than necessary memory use
Allow updating LDAP email address in Confluence

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-17509].
  {panel}

We don't yet have concrete data to detail exactly how much heap is consumed. However, we are certain that after the introduction of change documents in 3.0, the index has grown significantly larger (in terms of the total number of lucene documents). 

At minimum the no. of docs would have at least doubled, given that we do generate a change doc for the latest version of each piece of content on the system. 

Given that:

# field caches are arrays that are sized proportional to the document size of the index
# and the BitSet's used in all Lucene filtering operations are also sized proportional to the document size of the index

We are looking at higher memory consumption because we are allocating much larger arrays and BitSets, and filling them only very sparsely.
fields.summary: Reduce the memory/heap consumption of lucene filtering operations and field caches

fields.description:
Fixes originally added as part of CONF-2795 ensured uploading a new version of an attachment with a different case creates a new version of that attachment _but does not change its original filename_.

The RPC method addAttachment doesn't respect this. It has its own implementation which calls the AttachmentManager directly, rather than using the DefaultFileUploadManager like the attachment actions do.

The code for the remote API should use the same mechanism and have the same constraints as the attachment actions.
fields.summary: New version of attachment added via RPC changes case of file name

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

- create user with username 'test user'
- login as 'test user' and create a personal space
- Browse > Pages, Recently Updated - <confluence>/pages/recentlyupdated.action?key=~test+user

The error is:
bq. recently-updated: '~test' is not an existing space's key

*Update:* This no longer produces an error but displays "No recent updates found." Like Jeff said, this is because Confluence splits on spaces resulting in a query with 2 spaces. The suggested fix below works however, has an edge case (query with a personal space and global space mistaken for a personal space).
To address this problem, Confluence needs to be able to escape space delimiters.
fields.summary: SpaceKeyParameter could not parse space keys containing spaces (personal spaces)
